name: Mateo Abad
comment info:
When I look at the graph, I notice that the most popular nonsports entertainment programs have changed a lot over time. In the earlier years, weekly shows like NCIS and 60 Minutes often ranked near the top. More recently, though, live broadcasts such as the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade have taken over the highest spots. The Academy Awards still appear across the timeline, but not as consistently at the very top, which shows a shift from regular weekly shows to big one-time televised events.
    
    I think this change has a lot to do with streaming services. Since people can watch shows whenever they want online, fewer viewers tune in to traditional TV for weekly episodes. Live events, on the other hand, are special because they happen in real time, so audiences are more likely to watch them together. Cultural attitudes and changing interests probably play a role too--for example, some people may be less interested in award shows than they used to be.
    
    This connects to me and my community because most of us watch entertainment through streaming instead of cable or broadcast TV. We don’t usually watch the same shows at the same time anymore, unless it’s a holiday broadcast or a major live event. That means shared viewing experiences are less common now, and when they do happen, they’re usually centered around big cultural moments rather than weekly episodes.

replies.name: O
replies.comment info: @Mateo  I agree with your observations. The shift from weekly shows to big live events like the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade makes sense, especially with the rise of streaming services. Since people can watch shows anytime, there's less need to tune in for regular broadcasts. Live events, however, create a unique shared experience that streaming can't replicate. It’s interesting how cultural trends and new technology are changing the way we watch TV together.

In my community, people still gather to watch the parade live, but they rarely talk about watching the Oscars anymore. This shift in viewing habits might explain the changes. In this graph I notice that the top 10 most watched non-sports entertainment has change in the more recent years. For example, in the first column of the graph, "NCIS" is a very common show that is being watched. However, as the graph gets into more recent years, the presence of "NCIS" slowly declines and then fully disappears and seems to be replaced by "60 Minutes". I also can see that the Academy Awards held the spot for the most watched for many years in a row, and continued to stay in the top numbers consistently besides one year. Over all these years, it also seems that Macy's Parade has become more popular. Despite all these shows, though, the "other" category holds the most spots in the top 10 over the years shown compared to the other programs. 
    
    This makes me wonder what contributes to a show becoming one of the most watched programs? What contributed to "NCIS" practically being replaced by "60 Minutes"? Lastly, I would like to know what specific kind of programs fall under the "other" category?

name: Eyad D.
comment info:
1. I notice that the types of nonsports programs Americans watch the most have shifted significantly over the years. Earlier in the decade, the Academy Awards and shows like NCIS and 60 Minutes frequently appeared in the top 10. However, by 2020 and 2022, Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade dominates several of the highest-ranked spots. I also notice that the Academy Awards used to appear consistently but have gradually declined in the rankings in more recent years.
    
    2. I wonder why the Macy’s Parade grew so popular compared to other forms of entertainment programming. I also wonder whether the decline of award shows is due to changing viewing habits, like streaming replacing live TV, or if people are just less interested in those events. I’m also curious how the pandemic might have shifted audiences toward certain types of broadcasts and away from others.
    
    3. In my community, fewer people watch live TV unless it’s a major event. Most of us stream movies and shows on-demand, so long broadcasts like award shows feel less relevant. However, holiday traditions, like watching the Macy’s Parade, still bring families together in a way that other programs don’t. This graph reflects that shift: everyday TV shows aren’t the shared experiences they used to be, but big cultural rituals still draw large audiences.
    
    4. “From Award Shows to Holiday Spectacles: How America’s TV Priorities Have Dramatically Shifted.”

Earlier years had more variety, with the Academy Awards, “NCIS”, and “60 Minutes” appearing more often, but those programs seem to fade out as the years go on. I wonder why the Academy Awards lost so much popularity over the years and why the Macy’s Parade suddenly became one of the most-watched events. I also wonder if streaming services and changing viewing habits made it harder for regular TV shows to stay in the top 10 and whether the pandemic changed what people choose to watch on live TV. This relates to me and my community because most people I know no longer watch regular TV; instead, everyone uses streaming services. Holiday traditions, such as watching the Macy’s Parade, still bring people together, while shows like award ceremonies or dramas are not as important to talk about. "From Oscars to Parades: How America’s Viewing Habits Changed"

name: Santiago C.
comment info:
On this graph, I noticed a few things: NCIS was never too high, gonee by 2017, the Academy Awards have always placed fairly high, with the exception of a broadcast from 2021, the Macy’s Parade has been climbing in popularity over the past ten years on this chart, and 60 Minutes also began to rise in popularity in 2021 and 2022, taking up a nice chunk of the bottom 6-7 spots shown consistently during both.
    
    
    This graph leaves me questioning: How did the Macy’s Parade begin to rise in popularity? How have the Academy Awards stayed so consistently at the top? Why did 60 Minutes experience a boom in 2021 and 2022? What are the other programs that also made the top 10? Why is NCIS specifically on here?
    
    
    This graph reveals viewing trends in TV, showing the top 10 most-watched non-sports programs between 2013-2023. Making up the entire United States, it shows what we are and aren’t watching, and also leaves potential markers as for why with the window of years.
    
    
    A nice title for this graph may be The Top 10 Most Watched Nonsports Programs on Television between 2013 and 2023.

name: Connor Monosiet
comment info:
There has been a huge increase in viewership in watching 60 minutes and the Macy's parade. However, this has cost the viewership of NCIS and the Academy awards. This is likely a result of Covid, which caused many people to be isolate and fearful. This led to most people finding their own shows to watch. They also likely want to know what was going on in the world which resulted in an increase in viewership of 60 minutes which is a new program. A similar effect likely resulted in increase of the Macy's day parade viewership, as it provides a sense of connection as nearly everyone has seen it and it brings people together. I wonder though why NCIS viewership had dropped. I would likely assume that the show ended for the show to have stopped being watched. This relates to our town as many people watch television and it is nice to know what other people are seeing as you can then likely relate to them over shared interest in a show.
